params.text:
Professional Writing

Make Appointments:

Language in Action

• Propose an appointment
  • Change and confirm appointments
  • Dates and times
Professional Writing: Introduction

This module will equip you with the essential skills to schedule appointments clearly and professionally via email. 

You'll learn how to:

1. Propose an appointment by suggesting a time and date that works for you.

  2. Change and confirm appointments to reschedule or confirm existing appointments.

  3. Use dates and times correctly and professionally in your emails.
Propose an Appointment: Flashcards

dialogs.text: Would you be available to meet...
Does this time slot work for you?
Let me know what time works best for you.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is the purpose of David's email?
answers:
To schedule a meeting to discuss a marketing campaign. 

To inform Ms. Brown of a new product launch. 

To ask Ms. Brown for her opinion on a new product.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does David suggest for the meeting time?
answers:
He is available on Monday or Tuesday afternoon. 

He is only available on Monday afternoon. 

He is flexible and can meet any time next week.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does David ask Ms. Brown to do if the suggested times don't work for her?
answers:
To suggest an alternative time that works for her. 

To confirm the meeting for Monday.

To let him know if she can't meet next week.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Dear Ms. Brown,

I am writing to request a meeting to discuss the upcoming marketing campaign for the new product launch.

Would you be available to meet next week? I am available on Monday or Tuesday afternoon.

Alternatively, if those times don't work for you, please let me know what time works best for you.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

David Miller
Email:
Please read the following email and choose the best answer for each question about the email.
Propose an Appointment: Read & Quiz
Change And Confirm Appointments: Flashcards

dialogs.text: I am writing to confirm... (confirming an appointment)
dialogs.answer:
Use this phrase when you want to double-check the details of a meeting that has already been scheduled.
It ensures everyone is on the same page about the date, time, and location.

dialogs.text: I am writing to reschedule... (changing an appointment)
dialogs.answer:
Use this phrase when you need to change the date or time of a previously scheduled meeting.
It's important to inform the recipient as soon as possible and apologize for any inconvenience caused.

dialogs.text: Would it be possible to reschedule... (politely asking to change appointment)
dialogs.answer:
This is a more indirect way to request a change in meeting time.
It shows courtesy by asking permission to reschedule and expresses understanding if the original time doesn't work for the recipient anymore.

dialogs.text: I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. (apologizing for changing the appointment)
dialogs.answer:
It's always a good practice to apologize for any disruption caused by needing to reschedule a meeting.
It shows professionalism and respect for the recipient's time.

dialogs.text: Let me know if this new time works for you. (checking availability after suggesting a change)
dialogs.answer:
After suggesting a new time for the meeting, it's important to confirm if it works for the recipient as well.
This ensures everyone is available at the proposed time.

params.text: Change And Confirm Appointments - Sentences
Change And Confirm Appointments - Read & Quiz
Please read the following emails between Tarik and Alison and answer the questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Why did Tarik email Alison?
answers:
To reschedule their meeting about the sales report. 

To confirm their meeting on Monday. 

To discuss the sales report on Monday.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Tarik apologize for in his email?
answers:
Any inconvenience caused by rescheduling. 

Scheduling a client meeting on Monday. 

Missing Alison's meeting.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What time did Alison agree to reschedule the meeting for?
answers:
Wednesday afternoon. 

She didn't suggest a new time. 

Thursday afternoon.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Tarik:
Alison:

Subject: Reschedule Meeting - Sales Report Discussion

Dear Alison,

I am writing to reschedule our meeting on Monday to discuss the sales report. Unfortunately, a client meeting has come up that I cannot miss.

I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. Would it be possible to reschedule for later next week? I am available on Wednesday or Thursday afternoon.

Please let me know if either of these times work for you, or if there is another time that would be better.

Thank you for your understanding.

Sincerely,

Tarik

Subject: Re: Reschedule Meeting - Sales Report Discussion

Dear Tarik,

Thank you for your email and letting me know about the scheduling conflict.

No problem at all! Wednsday afternoon works perfectly for me to discuss the sales report.

See you then!

Sincerely,

Alison
Dates and Times: Flashcards

dialogs.answer:
Example: The meeting is in June.
The project is due in 2024. 
We usually go on vacation in the summer

Example: The meeting starts at 2 pm. 
We will meet at the office on Monday.

dialogs.text: On (days of the week, dates with a day)
dialogs.answer:
Example: We have a training session on Wednesdays.
My birthday is on December 15th.

params.text: Dates and Times - Read & Quiz
Please read the opinions of Jemima, Natasha, and Ben and answer the questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What does Jemima say about writing the date in emails?
answers:
She suggests using a clear format like "07 July 2024" to avoid confusion. 

She recommends writing the date out as "July 7th, 2024" 

It's not important to be specific about the date.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: According to Natasha, how do people in the US usually write the date for Independence Day?
answers:
They write it as "July 4th, 2024". 

They write it as "04/07/2024". 

They don't mention the year in the date.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Ben suggest if you're unsure about the time format someone uses?
answers:
Mention both the time in 12-hour format and 24-hour format. 

Mention both the time and date in your email. 

Ignore it and use your preferred format.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Jemima:
Natasha:

Jemima: I think it's important to write the date clearly in emails, especially for important meetings. For example, we say "07 July 2024" instead of "July 7th, 2024" in the UK. This way, there's no confusion about the day and month.

Natasha: In the US, we usually write the date like "July 4th, 2024" for Independence Day. It's important to know that some countries might write the date differently, so double-checking is always a good idea!
Ben:

Ben: I'm used to seeing times written in the 12-hour format with am/pm, like "10:00 am" for meetings. In some places, they might use the 24-hour clock, which can be confusing at first. If you're unsure, it might be helpful to mention both the time and time zone in your email.
Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question to demonstrate your understanding of the key skills for concluding professional writing effectively.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: How can you suggest a meeting time in an email?
answers:
Ask if a specific time would work for them. 

Tell the recipient the exact time you want to meet.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: What can you offer if the times you suggest don't work for the recipient?
answers:
Ask them to suggest a time that works for them. 

Tell them you can't meet at any other time.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: What phrase can you use to inform someone you need to reschedule a meeting?
answers:
I am writing to reschedule our meeting... 

I forgot about our meeting.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: How can you show you understand the inconvenience of rescheduling?
answers:
I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. 

It's no problem if you can't make it.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: What preposition do you use with days of the week?
Question 6 of 6: If you're unsure about the time format someone uses in an email, what can you do to avoid confusion?
answers:
Mention both the time and the date in your email. 

Ignore it and use your preferred format.
